DataElement.preferredDefinition: Numeric value for the critical organ volume at a rectum site receiving at least 40 Gray (Gy) radiotherapy dose.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Rectum RT Dose Greater Than or Equal To 40 Gray Critical Organ Volume
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The terminal portion of the gastrointestinal tract, extending from the rectosigmoid junction to the anal canal._A quantity of an agent (such as substance or energy) administered, taken, or absorbed at one time._A statement about the relative size or order of two objects specifying that either both objects are the same in quantity or measure or value or status or that the object of interest exceeds the other object in one of these ways._A number with no fractional part, including the negative and positive numbers as well as zero.::40_The SI derived unit of absorbed radiation dose. One gray is equal to an absorbed dose of one joule per kilogram of matter; one gray equals 100 rads. The unit is named for the British physician L. Harold Gray, an authority on the use of radiation in the treatment of cancer._The portion of the total volume of a critical organ that is exposed to a specified dose of radiation therapy.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The terminal portion of the gastrointestinal tract, extending from the rectosigmoid junction to the anal canal.

Concepts.definition: The terminal portion of the gastrointestinal tract, extending from the rectosigmoid junction to the anal canal.

Property.preferredName: Dose Greater Than or Equal To Integer::40 Gray Critical Organ Volume
Property.preferredDefinition: A quantity of an agent (such as substance or energy) administered, taken, or absorbed at one time. :A statement about the relative size or order of two objects specifying that either both objects are the same in quantity or measure or value or status or that the object of interest exceeds the other object in one of these ways.:A number with no fractional part, including the negative and positive numbers as well as zero.::40:The SI derived unit of absorbed radiation dose. One gray is equal to an absorbed dose of one joule per kilogram of matter; one gray equals 100 rads. The unit is named for the British physician L. Harold Gray, an authority on the use of radiation in the treatment of cancer.:The portion of the total volume of a critical organ that is exposed to a specified dose of radiation therapy.

Concepts.definition: A quantity of an agent (such as substance or energy) administered, taken, or absorbed at one time.

A statement about the relative size or order of two objects specifying that either both objects are the same in quantity or measure or value or status or that the object of interest exceeds the other object in one of these ways.
A number with no fractional part, including the negative and positive numbers as well as zero.
A SI derived unit of absorbed radiation dose. One gray is equal to an absorbed dose of one joule per kilogram of matter, or to 100 rads.
The portion of the total volume of a critical organ that is exposed to a specified dose of radiation therapy.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: the numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed as a fraction or ratio with 100 understood as the denominator.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Percentage; a fraction or ratio with 100 understood as the denominator.:A numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed.

Concepts.definition: A fraction or ratio with 100 understood as the denominator.
A numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed.

DataElement.changeDescription: Curated to support Duke University prostate cancer trial.
